Award.AwardTitle: Role of the COP9 Signalosome and its Subunit CSN5 in the Regulation of MAPK Pathways and Defense Responses in Tomato.
Award.AbstractNarration: Plants are exposed to many environmental stress signals. Generally they have efficient strategies for self-defense and protection. However, this efficiency may be compromised when plants are exposed to multiple stresses at the same time. Plants are not able to defend themselves effectively against certain pathogens while being attacked by insects and vice versa. The investigator has shown that the CSN5 protein operates as part of a molecular switch that determines whether defense responses to insects or pathogens will be activated. Another component of this mechanism is a MAP kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway that relays signals generated by insects and pathogens. This project will employ a molecular-biochemical approach to analyze how CSN5 regulates defense responses through interactions with MAPK pathways. This will uncover mechanisms that ?decide? what kind of defense responses will be activated. CSN5 plays a fundamental role for plant defense responses. This discovery is novel and this research project is aimed at identifying novel mechanisms of stress signal transduction which result in resistance to pests. Broader impacts. The outcome of the proposed research has the potential to provide novel strategies for generating multistress-resistant crop plants, but will also raise caveats regarding manipulation of signaling networks which may increase resistance to one pest but decrease resistance to another. The project will provide training opportunities in plant molecular biology for a postdoctoral research associate, graduate and undergraduate students. The investigator will also continue to recruit students from underrepresented groups and provide research opportunities for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major cause for suboptimal crop yield is environmental stress. This project is mainly concerned with damage and disease inflicted by herbivores and pathogens. These stressors contribute to enormous losses for US farmers, either by reducing yield of crop plants or through application of costly pesticides that may also be harmful to the environment. Understanding how plants perceive stress, relay the stress signals in their cells, and come up with defensive and protective stress responses is critical for developing strategies aimed at generating stress-resistant crop plants for sustainable agriculture.

We found that a multiprotein complex, the COP9 signalosome (CSN), plays a critical role for plant resistance against herbivorous insects and pathogens. Most defenses against herbivores and necrotrophic pathogens are mediated by the plant hormone jasmonic acid (JA), while defenses against biotrophic pathogens require salicylic acid (SA). We found that the CSN regulates JA-dependent defenses against herbivores and necrotrophic pathogens positively and SA-dependent defenses against biotrophic pathogens negatively. Together, these data indicate that the CSN is part of a molecular switch that determines whether JA- or SA-mediated defenses will be activated. (See enclosed figure.)

The CSN represents a hub in the stress signaling network and is known to be connected with other signaling components, e.g. via the ubiquitin-proteasome system that controls orderly protein degradation. MAP kinases (MAPKs) are essential signal relays in this network. We found evidence that the CSN and the ubiquitin-proteasome system regulate MAPK signaling, and that both physically interact. This represents a new mechanism for regulation of stress signal transduction.

As a signaling hub, the CSN assumes multiple functions in the cell. It is known to be essential for seedling development. In contrast, we found that its role in regulating the development of later life stages is not as pronounced. Later in life, the CSN rather plays a critical role in plant stress responses.

Systemin is a wound signaling peptide and required for resistance of tomato plants against herbivorous insects. We showed that systemin-induced resistance is controlled by the CSN. In addition, we found that overexpression of systemin results in constitutive release of volatile compounds that function in indirect plant defenses against herbivores. This expands the role of systemin beyond the previously known role in direct defenses.

This award contributed to the professional development of two postdoctoral researchers, four Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, and several graduate students from professional programs (PMS, MAT).  In addition, 13 undergraduate students gained research experience made possible through this award. They include 5 students from an underrepresented group in science (African Americans) and 5 students who received REU fellowships as a supplement to this award. One REU recipient won the prestigious national Barry M. Goldwater Scholarship. Most students presented their data as posters or talks, and many of them worked on their project for more than one semester. Two students wrote and defended a senior thesis for the USC Honors College. The award also supported research experience for a high school student through an RAHSS supplement.
